As related to us, it seems that for some infirmity he was submitting to a general ablution with alcohol.--During the process he was standing near a not stove,and when his skin was well moistened, the alcoholic vapor, drawn to the fire by the draft of the stove, flashed into a blaze which, as quick as thought, envaloped his whole body, greatly to the consternation of Mr. Stretch and his wife.
The flames soon lapped up all that fed them and subsided, but not till he had a pretty distinet glimpse of the feelings of John Rogers at the stake.

div3.head: The African slave trade.
div3.p: The provisions of the new treaty between the United States and Great Britain--commonly called the Seward Lyons treaty for the suppression of the African slave trade — are as follows:

1. Naval vessels of either power, when provided with special instructions for that purpose, may visit merchant vessels belonging to either when there is reasonable ground for suspicion that such vessels are slavers; and in order to fix the reciprocal right of search in such a manner as to avoid disputes, the following rules are agreed upon:

list.item: First.--It shall never be exercised except by vessels-of-war, authorised expressly for that object, according to the stipulations of this treaty.

Secondly.--The right of search shall in no case be exercised with respect to a vessel of the navy, of either of the two powers, but shall be exercised only as regards merchant vessels; and it shall not be exercized by a vessel-of-war of either contracting party within the limite of a settelment of port not within the territorial waters of the other party.

Thirdly.--Whenever a merchant vessel is searched by a ship-of-war, the commands of said ship shall, in the act of sodoing, exhibit to the commander of the marchant vessel the spemal instructions by whichhe is duly authorized to search, and shell deliver to such commander a certificate, signed by himself, stating his rank in the naval service of his country, and the name of the vessel of his country, and the name of the vessel he commands, and also declaring that the only object of the search is to ascertain whether the vessel is employed in the African slave trade, or is fitted up for the said trade.
When the search is made by an officer of the cruiser who isnot the commander, such officer shall exhibit to the captain of the merchant vessel a copy of the before mentioned special instructions, signed by the commander of the cruiser; and he shall inlike manner deliver a certificatesigned by himself, stating his rank in the navy, the name of the commander by whose orders he proceeds to make the search, that of thecruiser in which he salls, and the object of the search, as abovedescribed.
If it appears from the search that the papers of the vessel are in regular order, and that it is employed on lawful objects, the officer shall enter in the log-book of the vessel that the search has been made in pursuance of the aforesaid special instructions, and the vessel shall be left at liberty to pursue its coyage The result of the officer who makes the asarch must not be less man that of lieutenant in the navy, unless the command, either by reasonof death or other cause.
is t the time hold by an officer of infarior rank.

Forthty.--The reciprocal right of search and detention shall be exercised only withinthe distance of two hundred miles from the coast of Africa, and to the south ward of the thirty second parallel of north latitude, and within thirty leagues from the coast of the Island of Cuba.

div3.p: 2. All naval ships of the two nations assigned to the suppression of the slave trade shall be provided with coples of this treaty and the accompanying regulations; the names of such vessels to be reciprocally communicated by the two Governments; and seized vessels shall be sent to some place where a mixed court of justice
3. Owners of vessels illegally detained shall receive indemnity from the Government whose cruisers made the seizure; indemnity to be paid within one year from the judicial discharge of the case.

4. Three mixed courts of justice shall be established one at Leone, and one each at the Cape of Good Hope and New York, each court to be formed of an equal number of individuals of the two nations; the right of changing the place for holding these courts being reserved to each nation within its own territory.
These courts shall judge the causes submitted to them according to the provisions of the present treaty, and there shall be no appeal from their decision.
5. Officers who deviate from the regulation agreed upon shall be punished.
6. Every American or British merchant vessel may be seized as a slaver if the following articles are found among her equipments.
First.--Ratches with open gratings, instead of the close hatches which are usual in merchant vessels.
Second.--Civisious or bulkheads in the hold or on deck in greater numbers than are necessary for vessels engaged in lawful trade.
Third.--Spare plank fitted for laying down a second or slave deck.
Fourth.--Shackles, bolce, or handcuffs.
Fifth.--A larger quantity of water in or in tanks than is requirties for the consumption of the crew of the vessel as a merchant vessel.

Sixth.--An extraordinary number of water casks or of other vessele for holding liquid, unleess the master shall produce a certificate from the custom-house at the place from which he cleared outward, stating that a sufficeint security had been given by the ownors of such vessel that such extra quantity of caske or of other vessels should be used only to hold palm oil, or for other purposes of lawful commerce.
Seventh.--A greater number of mess-tubs or kids than requiste for the use of the crew of the vessel as a merchant vassel.

Eighth.--A boiler or other cooking apparatus of an unusual size, and larger, or capable of being made larger, than requisite for the use of the crew of the vessel as a merchant vessel, or more than one boller or other cooking apparatus of the ordinary size.

Ninth.--An extraordinary quantity of rice, of the flour of Brazil, of mamon or cassada, commonly called farina, of maize, or of Indian corn, or of any other article of food whatever, beyond the probable wants of the crew, unless such rice, flour, farina, maize, Indian corn, or other article of food, be entered on the manifest as part of the cargo for trade.

Tenth.--A quantity of mats or matting greater than is necessary for the use of the crew of the vessel as a merchant vessel, unless such mats or matting be entered on the manifest as part or the cargo for trade.

7. The discovery of any of the foregoing articles on board a merchantman precludes her owners from recovering indemnity.
even if the vessel should be discharged by the court

8. After condemnation, slavers shall be entirely broken up and sold in separate parts, unless either Government wishes to purchase them for its navy, in which case the court shall appoint an appraiser, and the Government whose cruiser made the capture shall have the first option of purchase.

9. The officers and crew of a condemned slaver shall be punished according to the lawe of the country to which such vessel belongs, as shall also the owner or owners and and the persons interested in her equipment or cargo, Onless they prove that they had no participation in the enterprise.

10. Negroes recaptured on board of slavers shall be placed at the disposal of the Government whose cruiser has made the capture; they shall be immediately set at liberty and shall remain free, the Government to whom they have been delivered guaranteeing their liberty.

The ratifications of the treaty are to be exchanged at London within six months from the date of its signature by Mr. Seward and Lord Lyons, (April 7,) and it is to remain in force for ten years from the day of exchange of the ratifications — and further, until the end one year after either of the contracting parties shall have given notice to the other of its intention to terminate the same, each of the contracting parties reserving to itself the fight of giving such notice to the other at the end of said term of ten years.

div3.head: Mistakes of physicians.
div3.p: --Oliver W. Holmes, in a lecture upon physiciaus, gives the following accounts of some mistakes which have been made in medicine.

Sooner of later everybody is tripped up in forming a disgnosts.
I saw Volnan one of the carotid arteries for a supposed aneurism, which was only a little harmless tumor, and kill his patient.
Mr. Dease, of Dublin, was more fortunate in a case he boloty declared an abecess, while others thought it an aneurism.
He thrust a lancet into it and proved himself in the right.
Soon after he made a similar diagnosis.
He thrust in his lancet as before and out gushed his pattent's blood and his life with it. The next morning Dense was found dead, floating in his blood.
He had divided the femoral artery.
I have doomed people and seen others doom them, over and over again on the strength of physical signs, and they have lived in the most contumaclous and scientifically unjustifiable marner as long as they some are living still.
I see, too, men in the street very often, who were as good as dead in the opinion of all who saw them in their extremity.
People will insist on living sometimes though manifesily moribund.
In Dr. Elder's Life of Kane you will find a story of this sort told by Dr. Kane himself.
The captain of a ship was dying of sourvy, but the crew mutinied, and he gave up dying for the present to take care of them.
An old lady in this city, near herend, got a little vexed at a proposed charge in he will; made up her mind not to die just then; ordered a coach; was driven twenty miles to the house of a relative, and lived for four years longer.
Cotton Mother tells some good stories which he picked up in his experience, or out of his books, showing the unstable equilibrium of prognosis.
Simon Stene was shot in nine places, and as he lay for dead, the Indians made two backs with a hatchet to out his head off. He go well, however, and was a lusty fellow in Cotton Mather's fines Jabes Musgrave was shot with a bullet that went in his our and came out of his eye on the other side.
A couple of bullets went through his body a so Jabes got well, however, and lived many years.
per contre, Colonel Rositee, cracking a plumbstone with his teeth, broke a tooth and lost hivlife.
We have seen physicians dying, like Spigelue, from a soratch; and a man who had a crowbar sent through his head is alive and well.
These extreme cases are warnings.
But you can never be too cautous in your progaosis, in the view of great uncertainty of the course of any disease not long patched and the many unexpected turns it may take.
The beautiful residened of Mrs. Ju A. Burnside, in Joune Ga., was completely consumed by fire on the 19th inst., No insurance.

div3.head: The Federals in North Alabama.
div3.p: A young lady in Hunisville, Ala., writes to her friends in Mobile in the following lively and spirited strain:

The Fev. Mr.--is here and preaches for us every Sunday; but he is not so partial to the President of the Confederate States that he connot leave him out of his prayers when neccesary.
He gets along very peaceably with the people.
Leat Sunday he prayed that the Lord would look upon as in mercy as we then stood before him — political enemies.
The church was helf filled with officers and high privates, all bedizzened out in blus broad cloth and gold lace and tassels, brase but tons and black feathers — strange to say, looked as calm and collected, after their agitated performances of the past week, as upon of buttermilk.

You should see them as they troop troop past the gate sometimes, on horseback, forty or fify of them together, with theri murderous looking spure attached to their heels, great long awords, cheased in brass and dangling with terrible clamor against the horses sides, wide leathern girdle, with innumerable dirks, pistols and bowie-knives attached thereunto, they in like manner clashing against each other with unmitigated fury — all of which, with the clatiering of the horses hoofs "upon the stony street," serve to produce an effect so horribly frightful that our faces are fever blanched with terror, and we instinctively pull our sun bounets over our faces and stop our ears with our fingers, that we may shut out as much as possible the terrifying and humiliating noise.

Ah! they are truly a brave set, and look so much like conquerors.
Napoleon himself could not have borne his "blushing honors" more gracefully than do these victorious Yankees ! And, in truth, they have reason to look like victory for did they not perform the unparalleled exploit of talling the city of Huntsville, with accounts of which all the Northern papers are teeming?
A city strongly fortified with the most impenetrable brick-houses, daring women, undaunted children, and furious bulidogs, the whole surrounded by a natural parapet of earth, stones, and giant trees, impervious alike to shell, ball, or sword!

And yet through all of this (the completion of which, I mus add, has occupled the citizens of Hunisville thirty years) these wonderful conquerors have made their war, and are now in possession of this moder.
Gibraltar. I will, however, say, for the edification of such as may have had friends of relatives converned in this affair, that not a drop of blood was eplit; the trees, finding they were overpowered by numbers, gave way, and allowed the enemy to pass unbarmed the stones, in like manner, retreated from "Camp Sinat" and took up a more desirable position near "Fort Retreet," which is near the base of the mountain; the daring women retired totheir catles, whilst compromise was entered into by the furious bulldogs and undaunted children, and a temporary armistice decided upon — the enemy, mean while, walking in and pitch their tents.
I cannot but think, when I look upon them, crowned with their freshly won laurels,of the Irishman, who, walking up to a dead man on the battle field, boldly cut off his head and held it up in triumph, and had much ado to persuade himself that it was in reality he, Pat, who had performed the wonderful feat!.

The enemy have, since their arrival in the place, procesded to lay waste all the plantations within their jurisdiction.
The third morning after their advent they marched, well armed and equipped, to Gen. W — plantation, where they succeeded in cepturing all the corn and bacon on the place, (comprising thirty or forty wagon leads,) and also taxing prisoners eighteen or twenty wild and spirited mules and horses who defended the place and themselves as well as could have been expected, and made all the resistance in their power.

div3.head: The different sentiments.
div3.p:
--A correspondent of the Central Presbyterian, writing from a portion of the State which has been alternately in the possession of the enemy and of our own forces, says there are, evidently, three parties in the Federal army in political sentiment.
He thus same them up:

list.item:
1st.
There is the Massachusetta party, who advocate complete subjugation, destruction of State Governments, and reducing the South to colonial dependence, and proceeding to this end by any and all means needed to effect it.

2nd.
The party who also aim at "the suppression of the rebellion" by unrelenting, uncomprising war, but then allowing political affairs to resume their old channels.

3d.
The third party hopes to combine concillatory measures with military force.
This is the and Republican party, who think that the Southern people are making war on the false idea that the North has become abolitionized, and would no longer do them juetice in the Union.
Their hope is that the North will, by putting Republicans out of office, and in a variety of other ways, convince the South of its error, appeace their hostile feelings, and induce them freely to return.
This party talk kindly to the people as they go along, and abuse the Messachusette party as roundly as the Southern people do.

div3.p: --The Army Argus, of the 13th inst., says:

q.p:
The bogus Governor Gamble, of Missouri, has called the convention to meet again on the first Monday in June.
The object of the call is expressed in the proclamation to be "for the purpose of re-districting the State and other purposes." What those "other purposes" are we do not know, but we predict that no atrocity left unperpetrated will be passed over by this body, which should be consigned to everlasting infamy.
Although called for one solitary purpose, to wit: to consider the relations of the State to the Federal Government as they existed on the 18th of February, 1861, this body has set aside the State Constitution, and boldly takes the ground that it is above the Constitution.
Whenever you quote any provisions of the State Constituiton, they coolly tell you that they are above that instrument.
Every man consenting to a principle so cestructive of all representative government, ought to be executed as an enemy to mankind.

div3.p:
A Cotemforary of Burns, recently daceased, has left behind him this verbal photograph of the favorite post in gude braid scets! "In a LI blue coat of his mither's making and dysing, eye; and of his mither's sewing in days; and his bonny black hair hinging down, and curling o'er the neck o't; a bulk in his han — aye a bulk in his hand, and whiles his bounet sheath his tither ockster, and didna ken that he was barsheaded; gnun about the dykesides and hedges; as just, that did little but read; and even on the hairst rig, it was soup and soup, and the baik — so up and soup, and then the bulk!
He wash a to very bonny man; dark and strong; but uncommon invitin' in his speech, uncommon.
Ye could na ha's cracked with him for a's minute, but stoodin' four or five!

div3.head: Interesting Problems.
div3.p:
--How drunk a man must be to be drunk is a question which used to be ther the old-fashioned tipplets.
How rich a man must be to be rich is an equally interesting problem, and admits an immense variety of answers.
"As rich as Crœrus" has been a standard comparison for several ages.
But Crœrus was only worth about $8,000,000, (eight millions,) and is therefore not worth mentioning by the side of Actor and the Rothachlids.
Yet Crœrus had a sung little property for a man of good habits and economical tastes, and had no reason to compain of his fortune.

div3.head: From Europe.
div3.p:
--By a recent arrival from Europe, we learn that the question of intervention is still kept promently before the public.
One of the British journels says that if a vote were to be taken inEngland upon American affairs.
an immenes majority of the people would be found in favor of the South
The people of Alabama are vigorously pushing forward works of defence on the Alabama river, against the enemy's gunboats, which, it is thought, will make an attempt to ascend that stream are long.

The Autauga Citizen announces that Thos.
at Ormsby, a well known citizen of Prattville, Alabama, was killed in the skirmish at Corinth on Tuesday evening last.
Ex. Governor Lows, of Maryland, with his family, is at present in Milledgoville, Ga., the guest of his brother-in-law, L. H. Brisoce Esq.

div3.head:
Depot army Committee Y. M. C. A., and ladies' soldiers' aid society,
Richmond, may 27, 1861
div3.p:
A Soldiers' Lodge, under the suspices of the Young Men's Christian Association of this city, has been in successful operation for several months.
The Army Committee regret to see notices in the local columns of our papers, stating that many soldiers are compelled, for want of better accommodations, to occupy at night "the steps of our publish buildings and the pavements of our stree's." is ample room for all trane out soldiers at the Lodge on 10th, between Main and Cary streets.

We will regard it as an act of kindness to our selves, as well at to the soldiers, if those who interest in their comfort would assist us in them to the Lodge.
Ample provision and comfortable quarters are furnished, free of charge.

div3.head: Jackson's late victory in the Valley.
div3.p:
Official dispatches received at the office Adjutant-General fully corroborate encouragements which appeared of yesterday.
In all respects the is complete, and the enemy in that hopelessly discomfitted.
The results victory it is needless to speculate.
The telegram which we append, ad to Adjutant-General Cooper, gives the important details of the engagement and the result attending them.

May 26.--During the last three God has blessed our arms with brilliant On Friday, the Federals at Front were routed, and one section of artillery in addition to many prisoners captured yesterday, Banks's main column, whilst from Strasturg to Winchester the rear part retreating towards On Sunday, the other part was at this place.
At last accounts Brig. Gen. H. Stewart was pursuing them a cavalry and artillery, and capturing A large amount of medical, ordnance, stores, have fallen into our hands.

The command of Colonel Ashby had gone to Martinsburg.

div3.head: Base Ingratitude.
div3.p:
Something over twenty years ago, a young stripting, of the name of Alex. Worrall, came to this city in the corps of Assistant Engineers for the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad Company, under the auspices of Moncure Robinson, Esq. This young man being a foreigner and friendless, excepting as to his patrons, was received with that-warm hearted kindness that our people to often extend to the stranger.
During the period of his residence here, he received every mark of kindness at the hands of our citizens; they took him in their houses and nursed him in sickness and misfortune, and placed him in lucrative offices.
He left Richmond about the time of the commencement of hostilities, and is now acting as engineer for the Yankees on the Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad.
We have never heard of a more palpable case of ingracitude.
The war will teach our people many lessons by which they will doubtless profit.

div3.head: The question of European recognition.

p.hi: To the Editors of the Richmond Dispatch:

div3.p:
Below you will and copies of letters addressed lately to the English and French Consuls in Richmond.
You are at liberty to publish them, if you consider that the public well face will be thereby promoted.

opener.salute: To the Consul of Her Britannic Majority, Richmond, Va.

div4.p: --Permit me to present to your consideration, as an Englishman, a few thoughts on our war that seem to me perfectly obvious which one may judge from their speeches and conduct, and the tone of the London Times do not appear to be so to the states men of your nation, and respectfully request you, if you think them worth notice to place them before your countrymen.

To the South it is clear (and I believe it must be so to every one who candidly exam into the matter that this war against her was designed by the Republican party from the moment this party sprang into existence.
For slavery they cared nothing.
It was merely the convenient stepping-stone by which taking advantage of the strong prejudice created by Mrs. Stowe's misrepresentations, they rose to power.
By the adoption of the Chicago Platform, by heaping upon us insults and threats by their persistent refuser, after the of their President, to give us any security that our constitutional rights should be respected, they intentionally goaded us into separating from them, and then, lost Europe should perceive their designs, by trickery cast upon on the odium of beginning the war. No doubt they hoped to subdue us more easily than they now flad to be possible, but the notice was sufficient to incite them to every effort.
The subjugation of the South has been from the first proclaimed as their object.
But do you clearly the quences to their success?

If once they can "cough out the rebellion." military commissions supported by armies, will soon dispose, by murder or banishment, of every human being in the South who could be dangerous to them, our property will all be confiscated to pay the expenses of the war and enrich themselves; their hordes will take our place in the South, and what a prospect of boundiest empire opens before them!
The country, like the world before the building of Babel, will be all, in the expressive Hebrew phrase, "of one lip." and their designs will be readily carried out. The negroes, nominally free will be reduced to the condition of peons, allowed a small pittance of waves to support themselves, and, getting in debt to their masters, will be compelled to labor for them so long as they are profitable, and then be turned off to starve.
But the Abolitionists will be satisfied, it is their own glory, not the good of the race, that they seek.

They will have all our ship timber, the best in the world, and the hint we have given them in the construction of the Virginia will read of their ships of war invulnerable.
With every requested in their own domains for physical prosperity, a "Morrill tariff" cutting off their name market from the manufacturers of Europe, and "developing their own resources;" a command of the grain market, that will enable them, when bad harvests afflict Europe, to create a famine there and an export duty on cotton, that will more than equalize the difference in the price of their labor and that of other countries, how can England, France, and Spain resist their dominion?
From the former, aided (if need be) by Russia, they will take her American possessions, including the fisheries, whose competition they have, from the last, Cuba and St. Domingo; from all, the markets of the world.
For, strive as they may, never will those powers be able to obtain elsewhere cotton so good and cheap as we can furnish to them.
Mexico, of course, will be theirs in time — an empire far greater than ever Napoleon could have attumed to.

See, in contrast to this, what assisting us will give to the European powers.--All we ask is recognition, and the raising of the blockade, that we may receive your manufactures (including munitions of war) in return for our crops.
Our independence once established, the power of the North is broken, and she can no more be dangerous.
We offer to England and France our coasting trade, our law material in exchange for their manufactures, and to Canada the market for her fish, potatoes, and other products, which has been heretofore monopolized by the North.
Had those powers united with Spain, recognized us, raised the blockade, and taken our crops last December, when the North was cowed by the resolute conduct of England in reclaiming our Commissioners, they would have had, no war. The indignation of the Northern people would have been turned against their Republican leaders, and they would have occupied themselves with putting them out of power.
Now that these are flushed with partial success, interference may cost those powers a war; but since the battle must be fought by them either at our door or their own, is it not better it should be done now while we can aid and reward them?
In not coming out for us last December, it does appear to me that English statesmen committed what Talleyrand denounced as "worse than a crime — a blunder" Hoping they may yet repair it, and wishing them better judgment in future, I am very respectfully,

closer.signed: A Refuges from the Valley of the Mississippi.

div4.p: A copy of the above was sent to the Consul of France, with the following note.

Monsient — Your courtesy will pardon any errors I may commit in the mode of addressing you, when I tell you that my life has been mostly passed in quiet country places, and thus I am ignorant of your name or of anything but the simple fact that there is a gentleman in Richmond who is the French Consul there.
For addressing you at all I can offer no excuse but the urgency of our affairs, and the great concern which it appears to me France has in them.

Enclosed is a copy of a letter which I took the liberty of writing to the British Consul a few days since.
I send it to you because it contains views which address themselves also to French interests.
They may be familiar in all their aspects to both nations; but how, in that case, the statesmen of those nations could consider this as a matter in which they were bound to be neutral, I cannot understand.
Do they not see the intense apprehension of the United States lest they should perceive and foil her designs, which are almost as much against those powers as against ourselves?
So gigantic a scheme of robbery and wrong has never yet been conceived since the days of that great robber, Rome, and the worse on the part of the United States, as she has so loudly asserted the inherent right of man to self government.
No wonder Russia should be her friend, it throws the partition of Poland into the shade, and no doubt Seward has promised that power that the fall of Sebastopot shall be avenged.--What can hinder it, if they are allowed by their naval superiority to "crush out the rebellion" and consolidate their power over us?
The rebellion!
What audacious wrong to call it so?
Our revolution of was indeed a rebellion, for England had rights over her colonies which one act of States cannot pretend to have over another, and which were expressly denied to them when our Constitution was formed.
But lust of power and wealth, and hatred of us, have been their sole guides; and, in pursuit of their gratification, you see now all constitutional restraints have been spurned by them.

If the North is permitted to go on unchecked, you lose all our cotton for this year and the next; for last year's crop will surely be burfied before she shall have it, and the growing crop ploughed up. After that, should she succeed, I have shewn in the enclosed how clearly her interest is concerned in placing such an export duty on what she can raise as shall give her the advantage of you in the markets of the world, besides the great loss to you of the market of the South.

I have no apology to offer for any presumption but the desire to do good.
Accept the latter, and for its sake pardon the former.
div4.closer:
Very respectfully, your servant., A Refuge from the Valley of the Mississippi.
Lynchburg, Va., May, 1862.

argument.p: the Capital of Louisiana--Confederate currency in New Orleans — battle of Glorietta.

div4.p: --The Vicksburg Waig, of the 21st, says that Baton Rouge is still in our possession.

It is stated that the foreign Consuls at New Orleans have protected against the suppression of the Confederate currency, and that the English and French owners of cotton burnt at New Orleans were making out bills against the Federal Government for their loss.

The Houston (Texas) Telegraph, of the 7th, contains the particulars of a battle at Glorietta.
The Courier says that the enemy left five hundred killed and wounded on the field, and lost besides two hundred.
The Confederate loss was sixty- eight killed and wounded, including Major Requet, Capt. Huckhaltz and Major Shropshire.

div3.head: Latest from Vicksburg.
div3.p:
--All quiet here.
Two vessels arrived at the fleet to-day.
It is supposed that the Yankees are awaiting reinforcements.
Our men are eager for the fight.

div4.p:
On the 22d inst., at "The Farm," near Charlottesville, Va, of "Roberts Rosales, daughter of Thos.
L and Julia Fa in the 9th year of her age.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, May 27th, at the residence of Mrs. H. E. B on Catharine street, William H. Lee, Jr. of the Williamsburg Junior Guards, Thirty-second Regiment Virginia Volunteers, in the twenty second year of his age.

The deceased, at the call of his country, was among the first who enlisted in the defence of the land of his birth.
Shortly after the evacuation of the Peninsula he was taken sick, and, on his arrival in the city of Richmond, was sent to the Louisiana Hospital, where he soon succeeded in getting permission from the attending surgeon to be removed to the above mentioned residence, where he was very kindly received and most sympatheticully attended to.
The deceased leaves behind a father and mother, who reside in the city of Williamsburg, by whom he was affectionately idolized.
The funeral obsequies will take place at the above-mentioned residence, at three o'clock P. M. Friends and acquaintances are respectfully invited to attend.

div3.head: Great Inducements to Volunteers.
div3.p:
--the Militia again in the field!--Governor Letcher has called upon the patriotism of the people for the purpose of acting as a Guard for this city and its various prisons; and to save the humiliation of a draft, Capt. Warner Lewis, with able assistants, have commenced the organization of a Battalion for the purposes above alluded to. He offers a bounty of Fifty dollars and the usual clothing and pay. Only a few more recruit needed to complete the number.
This corps is for local purposes only, and will not be sent away.
Good quarters and subsistence from the time of enlistment.

The undersigned will be pleased to receive the names of those desiring to enlist having been authorized to do so by Capt. Lewis.
He can be found at Mr. John McDonald's Store, corner of Broad and Twenty-fifth streets or at the Dispatch Office, when at recruiting.
div3.closer: my 28--3t Ed C Crump.

div3.p:
I am authorized by the Governor and Major General John B Floyd, to recruit a company of Cavalry or Monntrel R flag, to serve for the term of twelve months, to the State forces.
Persons joining this company will have quarters and subsistence furnished them from the time of enlistment.
Those furnishing horses will receive twenty-four dollars per month, those to whom horses are furnished twelve dollars per month.
We are anxious to go immediately into service.
For further particulars require at office, opposite Spot wood Hotel.
div3.closer:
Edw'd McCONNELL Jr,
Capt, Cavalry, Gen. Floyd's Division.
my 23--3t*

div3.head: Deserters.
div3.p:
--A reward of thirty dollars each will be paid for the following named men, who have straggled off from my company since we left Richmond for the Peninsula.
They are believed to be now lurking about Richmond, as some of them have been seen to the last few days.
Oswold Wright.
The above reward of thirty dollars will be paid for the delivery of each to my company near Oskwood Cemetery.
div3.closer:
P. Woodfolk, Jr.
my 28--3* Capt. Albard artillery.

div3.head: Deserters.
div3.p:
--The following rewards will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me of the persons whose names are subjoined, and who have deserted from the steamer Patrick Henry: Mathew Kennedy.
$100; John H. Howard, Patrick Murphy, Coleman Nte Jerry Brady, Angus McDonald, Joseph Walker, Joseph M. Thurston, (a negro,) Jno. A. Pearson, Thomas Siddons, William Murphy.

div3.p: All members of this Regiment now absent, either with or without leave, will report to those Headquarters in person, or by Surgeon's certificate, by Thursday morning, 2th instant otherwise they will be reported as deserters, and arrested and punished as such.

E. M. Butt Col. Comd'g.

div3.head: Attention Young men of the city.
div3.p: All young men, between the ages of 16 and 18, residing, west of 14th street and one mile beyond the corporation limits, will assemble promptly at City Hall, this (Wednesday) evening, at 4 o'clock, for drill.
div3.closer:
By order of
Wm. C. Figner, Captain.
L B. Tatum, O S. my 28--1t*

div3.p:
--Commandants of Regiments, Brigades and Divisions will find the name of all the men returned to duty from the five Chimborazo Hospitals posted daily at the doors of the Steward's officer.
The men will be delivered in charge of any authorized guard or escort upon application.
div3.closer: my 28--2t J B McCAW Surgeon.

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p: --Runaway on the night of Sunday last the 25th inst. five Negroes, engaged in cutting wood in Chesterfield county for the Virginia from Manufacturing Company.
Caztef, is about thirty-five years of age, about five feet seven inches high and of a gingerbread color.
Archer, is about thirty years of age about six feet high, very black, thick lips, and has a very feminine voice.
Jacob is about twenty-eight years of age five feet six inches high, yellow, and quite stout.
William, is twenty-five years of age, nearly six feet high black, speaks in a low tone.
Walking is forty-five years old six feet high, of a gingerbread color inclined to stoop while walking.

A reward of ten dollars apiece will be paid for each one of the above, it delivered either to Mr. J. D. Gardner, at Friend's farm, in Chesterfield county, or to Mr. P. O'Nell, at the Westham Iron Works, Lock No. 3d J R. & K.
Thos. H. Wynne.
my 28--1w Prea't and Agent I M Co.

$40 reward will be given for the delivery of my servant Anna to my agent Caleb W Walking, in Danville.
She is of a dark brown color, in her fourteenth year; with woolly hair.
The girl has been hired for a long time to Mary Winfred, a free mulatto woman, on the northwestern suburbs of Richmond, who has unbounded influence over her. When I sent for her, on the 19th of this month, to go to Danville with her mother and other negroes, Mary Winfred failed to deliver her. This and other good reasons, satisfy me that this free woman has concealed her in the city, or sent her to the country.
She may be looked to for this concealed negro girl.
my 28--4t Wm. M McCABTY.

div3.head: $25 reward
div3.p:
--Runaway, about the 15th day of May, a Mudatto Boy, about five feet five inches high, twenty-seven years old, named Sandy.
Left me at Long Bridge, on the Chickahominy river. $25 reward will be paid to any one who will return said boy to E. H. Stokes at Stokes's Hotel, Richmond, Va.
Lieut. Wiley C. Tunstall,
my 28--5* Co. D, 5th Ala Reg't.

div3.head: Boy lost or Runaway
div3.p:
--From the American Hotel.
on the 20th inst, a black negro boy, named Doss, 36 years old; weighs 150 lbs. The boy was sent in my charge from Madtson Ga., and belongs to young Ogilby, in the Third Georgia regiment, now at Petersburg.
A liberal reward will be paid for any information or delivery to W. P. Moon, at Dians Hotel, or to his owner at the regiment.
Capt. W. J. Ballard.

div3.head:
[from the Charleston Mercury.]
"Away with the Dastards who Whine of Defeat"
by Paul E Hayne.
div3.p:
["One of the most melancholy productions of an era of strife and convulsions, is the Snive a biped that infests all clarses of society, and prattles eternally from the Catechism of Despaird.
A babyish, nerveless fear has driven the sentiment of hope from his soul.
He cringes to every phantom of apprehension, and obeys the impulses of cowardice as though they were the laws of exctence His life is the embodiment of whise! He is ridden by an eternal nightmare, and emits an everlasting Wall!"--Whipple]

opener.salute: To the Editors of the Dispatch

div4.p:
Northern papers bring us the sad tidings of the murdering of our young friend Harry Stewart, (formerly of Baltimore, but lately of this city.) by Linsoln's hirelings, while attempting to escape from the Old Capital Prison, at Washington city.
Thus has one of Maryland's noblest and best sons fallen rather than take the acc oath of allegiance to the Yankee Government Btewart risked his life to gain that for which he so periled — Liberty.
Surely he has died a noble death, and the future historian can but do justice to his memory in classing him among the first of those brave and heroic sons of Maryland who have fallen in defence of Southern rights.

Stewart was among the number who welcomed the Yankee hirelings at Baltimore on the memorable 19th of April, 1861. For some time he was a member of Ashby's celebrated cavalry, and in December last, while on a visit to his parents, was arrested by the Yankee detectives, and ever since has been confined in that accursed dungeon.
That alone is misery far worse than my feeble pen can describe.

Now, Marylanders, 1st us to the "battle-field" and revenge this heros's death and the many wrongs our "good old State" has on dured.
Do not, I pray you, be idle while Virginia's bast sons are offering their all in defence of our cause.
Let us make the "Old Maryland Line" in this war, as our fathers old in former ones, farmous and renowned for deeds of valor.

Will you not. I ask, leave this "fair and beautiful city for the stern realities of war?
Let us all unite, and with one die in the attempt.
Our fathers at home anxiously await our coming "Stonewall" will lead us to our own firestdes.
Then join the little band now on its way.

opener.salute: To the Editors of the Dispatch

div4.p: I wish to call the attention of the public authorities, hrouph your columns, to a matter which theyhave falled to rememner the multiplicity of subjects of momens now demanding their attention.

We have now many troops in camps of instruction without arms.
The history of every conflict establishes the supperior spirit and impernosity of our troops over those of the enemy, and in every instance he has been driven back, if not eventually vanquished, with the loss of arms, munitions and stores on the field, most of which were recovered by him ultimately on account of the inability of our soldiers to bear them to the rear.
One or two thousand men as a morking force, with suitable arrangements, where a great battle is expected, could save all of this property, arm themsalves, and act as a reserve, if necessary.
The losses at Shiloh and Williamsburg of our imperial spoil demoustrate the neccssity of a working, as wall as a dighting force.

div3.head:
The New Mormon Complication.
[from the New York post, April 30th.]
div3.p:
Brigham Young has just been insugurated as Governor of the new State of De et, and Mr. Ashley's bill for the punishment of polygamy has passed the House of Representatives.
Here is a conflict at our doors at once.
The Mormous have organized their State Government with polygamy as the "corner stone" of their system, just as slavery in the corner stone of the Confederates, intending to demand immediate admission into the Union.
While Congress declares their fundamental system a crime which morals and justice alike forbid.

That the Mormans — are in earnest in their new State morvement is abundantly proved by the recent public speeches of their leaders — Brigham Young, Hebar C. Kimball, and other "apostolic" Dignituries in Utah, who mould the deluded followers of the Mormon beresy at their will, boidly avow their purpose to make a direct issue with the Government.--In effect, they say that they have suffered unjust persecution until for bearance is no longer a virtus, and that they now insist upon a full recognition of their rights, on an equal footing with the States.
Young himself expressed the sentiments of Mormen priesthood in a violent philipple, which we find reported in the D News, official organ.
Here is a single passage:

q.p:
"We are not going to be with a mere pre-emption right on the soil in this territory Should the Government grant to every head of a family six hundred and forty acrss of land, and to each wife and child their pertion, as was done in Oregon territory, that would give to me and to my sons and daughters quite a scope of country, and the whole people would swallow up all the land in this territory.
But shall we be satisfied with that?
No; I am going to have a larger pre-emption than the territory of Utah.
In a few years this territory will not contain my own posterity.
In twenty years from new this spacious hall will not hold them, and in twenty years more they will more than fill this territory.
I cannot put up with this small possession."

div3.p:
Brigham's wants, like his wives, are many, and, according to this speech, so are his ambitions pians.
The News, echoing his language, puts the case still more plainly:

q.p:
"The people have spoken and in language not to be mistaken have declared their aversion to colonial servitude, tyranny, and oppression, and that they with to supercede the Territorial frorm of Government to which they have submitted for nearly tweive years by a State Government of their own formation, in accordance with the principles of the Constitution of their common country, to which they are so much attached.
They have for a long time been deprived of their political rights, and they now feel like asserting them, and relieving the Federal Government from the expenses accruing from the unconstitutional arrangement instituted by Congress for governing Territories as far as relates to the rule of Utah.

Here is the beginning of a new trouble.--The Government will probably soon be compelled to choose between the admission of Mormons to the full privileges of citizens, or the forcible suppressionof something which will resemble rebellion.
Unscrupulous, scheming, and crafty, the Mormon leaders will leave no means untried to compass their ends.
They lend a great population of fanat in the blindest, most abject and unreasoning subjection, and possess — resources which have been literally wrested from the defert by dint of hard labor and unwearying enerty.
Ones they succombed to a timely show or the strength of the Federal power; but it now seems that they are ready to re-enter the lists and by the of

div3.head: Maryland Mounted Rangers.
div3.p: --Having received the proper authority, We desire to place in the field, in as short a period as possible, a Maryland-Partisan Cavalry Company, to act as far as pracitcable on the frontiers of our own State.

The partisan service, as regards health and the excitement necessary to the life of a soldier, is instly considered for preferable to any other.
In addition to the $50 bounty, pay, and rations, which are the same us in the regular cavalry, all arms, hortes, and coniraband property, of every description captured from the enemy, will be sold and the procecds divided among the members of the corps.
Horses and all necessary equlpments positively furnished to those unable to precure them.

This company will form a portion of the Maryland Partisan Corps, now being organized in the city of Richmond, to be composed of cavalry, artlltery, and infantry, and which will be commanded by Col. Walter H. Jenifer.
Re-enlisted Marylanders, or those serving unexpired terms, will, upon furnishing us with their names, be immediately trensferred.
Those wishing to join this company would do wall to make early application, as the full complemant is nearly made up.
Ricruiting Office--Assistant Provost Marshal's Building, Frankling street, below Exchange Hotel.
div3.closer:
Capt. Thomas I. McKAIG,
Lieut. E. Duval,
my 27--1w* Late of the 7th Regt. Va. Vols.

div3.head: Citadel Guard.
div3.p:
The undersigned having been authorized by the Secretary of War, through Brigarder.
General Winder, to raise a company of infentry for garrison, guard and prison duty, in the city of Richmond, requests-thote who may prefer this service to enlist in this company.
Any good man not already in the service will be received.
Persons between the ages of 35 and 45, soldiers who have been discharged from the service and are again willing and able to do duty, are earnestly desired in this way to contribute to the safety of the city and Confederacy.
Usual clothing and bounty money given, with subsistence until the company is fully organized.
Further information can be obtained by application to the subscriber, at Gen Winder's office.
div3.closer:
Warner Lewis,
A. D. C. to Brig.-Gen. John H. Winder.
my 27--2t*

div3.head: Desertions.
div3.p:
--On the 10th inst. Timotry Crean, alias Curtin.
Said Crean is about five feet seven inches-high-sallow complexion, blue eyes and dark hair, with rather a down look.
He had also a considerable won on the top of his head.
A legal reward will be given in any one for apprehending him and notifying me of the last.

On the 70th inst., George Foster.
Said Foster is about five feet eight Inches high, florid complaxion, hazle eyes light hair, and face somewhat marked with small-pox.
He is a Scotchman by birth, and lauguage earlly detected by fornign secent.
He has also one luft upper front tooth missing.
A legal reward will be given to any persen for apprehenoing him and notifying me of the fact.
div3.closer: R. C. M. Page. my 27--6 * Captain Morris Artillery.

div3.p: the following members are absent from my company without leave, if they do not return immediately, they will be advertised as deserters, and treated accordingly.
div3.closer:
Claiburne Bass.
Emmet. W. Weisiger,
Comd'g Mancheater Artillery.
Gordensville, Va. May 24, 1862. my 27-- t*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All absenfess of my Company, including all those who were members of Capt. Wm. H. Orank's Company, are hereby ordered to report at once to Col. H. C. Pats at Richmond or they will be dealt with as descrters.
div3.closer: R. B. Boston. Captain. my 27--3t* Pate's Cava'ry.

div3.head: A fine Opportusity for Profitarle Employment.
div3.p: --Any person well acquainted in the city fo Richmond, who will recruit for Capt. Lorris's Company, which is about to be organized for Local defence can be profitably employed by calling at the Recruliing office on Main street, immediately in frontof the entrance to the Sp is of Hotel.

W R. Lindsay will be pleased to confer with members of the quondam Dickinson's Artillery.
Those jaining Bayly's Heavy Artillery will recsive 850 bounty, and two moths' back pay. Apply at the corner of 12th and Franklin streets.
div3.closer:
W. R. Lindsay,
my 26--6t* Recrulting Sergsant.

div3.head: For Local defence
div3.p: --Having received anthority to raise a company for local defence at the Seat of Government, those wishing to enlist will apply immediately at the Recruiting Office on Broad, between 6the and 7th streets, from 8 A. M. to 2 P. M. and from 4 to 6 P. M.

div3.head:
Headquarters Co. F, 23d Va. Vols,
army of the Valley.
div3.p:
Deseeters.--Private John T. Warrener.
of Company F, after receiving his bounty and furlongh, has never returned.
Said Warrener is about 21 years of age; medium size; red, blufly lace; curly hair, and altogether has a had countinance.
Upto the time of re-enlistment, he had been of very little service to his company His is supposed to be lurking in the neighborhood of Rocketer.

On the 5th of May, private S P. Johnson, aged 38 years. He, by his previous course of con seem, entirely indisposed to serve his country.
whatever is due the above-named men will be paid for their delivery at camp.
Other members of this corps absent on sick furionghs, will report immediately at headquarters. --If unable by sickness, they will send a Surgeon's certificate to that effect.
div3.closer: my 20--14t* T. S. Michaels, Captain.

div3.head:
Attention!
Marylanders.
div3.p: The undersigned is authorized by the Secretary of War to enlist a Partisan Company of Marylanders, to be attached to the Maryland Line, under the orders of Brigadier-General Steuart; to be enlisted for the war, and to receive the same bounty, ($50,) pay, &c., as other volunteers.
Horses will be furnished by private contribution to those who are unable to procure them, and the Government will furnish arms and equipments where needed.

Native or adopted citizens of Maryland now in the service, in any regiment other than the 1st Maryland regiment, who wish to join this arm of service, can be transferred under General Order No. 8, Special Order No. 107, by application to Major Geo H. Kyle, or to
div3.closer:
G. M. Emack,
Lt. C. S. A. and Recruiting Officer,
my 23--1w* No. 14 Pearl st., Richmond.

div3.head: Partisan troop for Kentucky and Tennessee!
div3.p:
--I am authorized to raise a Partisan troop for operations in Kentucky and Tennessee.
Those who wish to join in this "dashing," "dare-devil" business, and serve their country like good and true men, can do so by applying to me. --There will be $50 bounty granted by the Government, and the troop will be well mounted and thoroughly equipped!
None but sound; good, dashing fellows need apply; for as the service will be chivalrous, adventurous, and dangerous, none but unexceptionable young men will be received.
Those who wish to emulate Morgan and his troop have now an opportunity by applying to
div3.closer:
Capt Wm. H. Rowan.
No. 13, Columbian Hotel, 13th street.
my 23--6t*

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
In consequence of not being able to purchase horses in Richmond, I have deemed it best to make Lynchburg the point of rendezvous for my company of Pertisan Rangers.
Additional members will be received.
The attention of those desiring to join my company is called to the fact that they wil be furnished with horses and equipments, and the usual bounty of $50 will be paid.
My office, on Bank, near 10th street, will be kept open, where transportation to place of rendezvous can be had. I am anxious to go into service at an early day; hence, those who feel disposed to join my company will please report at once.
div3.closer: my 26--6t* L. R. Smoot.

div3.head: Maryland Line.
div3.p:
--I am authorized to raise an Inpantry Company for the Maryland Line.
Citizens of Maryland desiring to unite themselves with the line.
are invited to join me.--The company will elect its own officers.
I can be found for the present at the Pay Office of the Confederate Forces, corner of Bank and 10th streets. Bounty and transportation furnished without delay.
div3.closer:
Campbell W. Pinkney.
my 22--t31stM* Of Maryland.

div3.head: Attention, Martin's Battery!
div3.p: --All members of this command who are absent without leave, will report at once at "Came Lee," or they will be reported to the Provost Guard and arrested as deserters.
Persons wishing to join the company will apply to Serg't Pulliam, at the Recruiting office, corner of Bank and 12th streets.
div3.closer:
S. Taylor Martin, Captain.
ap 31--ts.

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive Substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefors, who desirs to procurs substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnsen & Guigon's office, under the Whig ding.
div3.closer:
A. B. Guigon.
mh 28-- Captain Light Artillery

div3.head: Maryland Partisan corps.
div3.p: --It is proposed to organise a Partisan corps of Maryland men, to act as nearly ast possible on the frontier of our own State.
The corps to consist of Cavelry, Artillery and infantry and to be under command of Colonel Wal H. Jen who has the same.
Horsct will be furnished to those who desire to in the cavalry, if unable to provide their own.

The Secretary of War having decided that Marylanders are excmpt from the provisions of the Conscription act, all twelve months men from that State can claim transfer to this corps at or after the expiration of their term of service.
Pay, rations and bounty same as in regular service.
div3.closer:
J. A. Weston,
my 10--ts 15 Pearl street.

div3.head:
Heasq'rs Dep't Henrico,
may 25th, 1862.
div3.p: an Appeal to the people of Richmond.
In order to obviate, if possible, the disagreeable necessity of impressing hands for Government work, an appeal is again made to the people.
All hands voluntarily offered will be paid one dollar per day, payment made weekly if required so long.
div3.closer:
John H. Winder,
my 26--1w Brigadier-General.

div3.head: Maryland Partigan corps.
div3.p: The attention of Maryland and District men is called to this service, to which they are so particularly adapted, and which will give them the best opportunity to avenge the insults offered to our glorious old State.
Alredy three entire companies of the 1st Maryland regiment have joined, and a majority from several of the other companies have requested to be transferred.
This corps will be independent of all other commands, save that of the General commanding the Department of Virginia, and will act as nearly as possible on the frontiers of Maryland.

As the Conscription act does not apply to Marylanders, they occupy the same position as though it had never been passed, and hence all 12 moths men can claim transfer to this corps, if re- enlisted; or, if not re-enlisted, can be discharged upon or after the expiration of their term of service.
Horses will be furnished those who desire to join the Cavalry and are unable to provide their own.
In addition to the pay, rations, and bounty, (which are the same as in regular service,) the value of all captures from the enemy will be distributed among the men.
The corps will be composed of Cavalry, Artillery, and Infantry, and commanded by a distinguished officer of the army.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining the command will apply to
div3.closer:
J. A. Weston,
my 14--ts 15 Pearl street.

div3.head: Partisan Rangers.--
div3.p:
My Battalion of Mounted Rangers will be ready to take the field in two weeks. Only one more company required.
Those wishing to unite will please address me immediately.
div3.closer:
Lt. Col. W. C. Claiborne.,
my 10--ts Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Attention, Marylanders!
div3.p: --The undersigned is alone authorized to recruit for the Maryland Line.
The attention of all Marylanders is called to this organization, and to the necessity of perfecting it as speedily as possble.

Under the late Conscription Act, Marylanders who are enlisted for twelve months, are entitled to their discharge at the expiration of that time; and to such discharged men a bounty of $50 will be paid upon their re-enlistment, and the option given them of entering either arm of service — artillery, cavalry, or infantry, and of electing their own officers.

Transferred men from other regiments, under General Orders No. 8, and Special Orders No. 107.
from the War Department, are entitled to the same rights of service and election, and by the act of Congress authorizing such, transfers can only be made to the Maryland Line.
div3.closer:
George H. Kyle,
No. 14 Pearl street,
Major and Recruiting Officer Maryland Line.
my 20--5tood (if)*
